posts.post_content:
As wolfbear2 noted, this could be a bomb in dredge, especially in a casual deck when combined with the keyword dredge itself (I'm not sure if he meant the archetype or the keyword).   
Once you've gotten something with dredge in your graveyard (with a turn one [Careful Study](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Careful Study), perhaps?), you wont have any problems getting the rest of your deck there.  
  
The biggest minus though ought to be the double blue cost, but that shouldn't be too hard to get around with all mana fixing available

posts.post_content: At first I thought this was good because I misread the part about "from your library". Then realized it's pretty awful. If it let you draw without paying a cost, or triggered when a land went to your graveyard from play, it might be useful. As it is, pretty worthless except a few extremely rare corner cases (the aforementioned dredge decks).

posts.post_content:
This card deserves a much higher rating. Just because it can't fit into any old deck doesn't make it bad.  
  
Like aforementioned, run this with [Jace's Erasure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace's Erasure) and something that reveals the top card of your library, such as [Wizened Snitches](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wizened Snitches) or [Sphinx of Jwar Isle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sphinx of Jwar Isle). Whenever you draw a card, you get to take a look at the next card up; If it's a card you don't want you can mill it with the erasure, if you want the next card though you can keep it there and mill your opponent's top card instead (if it's good, that is). If your next card is a land and you don't need it, mill it then draw again. This card could be an especially efficient deck thinner if ran with Scry cards or cards with Scry-like functions such as [Sage Owl](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sage Owl). Need I not mention [Crucible of Worlds](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crucible of Worlds); ensure a land drop almost every turn and even more card acceleration.  
  
Now if you'll excuse me gentlemen, I'm off to build a deck.... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:

Whenever you draw a card, you get to take a look at the next card up; If it's a card you don't want you can mill it with the erasure, if you want the next card though you can keep it there and mill your opponent's top card instead (if it's good, that is). If your next card is a land and you don't need it, mill it then draw again. This card could be an especially efficient deck thinner if ran with Scry cards or cards with Scry-like functions such as Sage Owl. posts.post_content:
I tried this rogue blue/ white standard deck back in Odyssey block that would mill itself using stuff like [Mental Note](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mental Note), [Think Tank](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Think Tank), [Reviving Vapors](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reviving Vapors) or even [Cephalid Vandal](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cephalid Vandal) to get big stuff into the graveyard... Pedantic Learning would be a handy way to draw counters and bounce while I was doing that. The goal was to [Breath of Life](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Breath of Life) an [Ancestor's Chosen](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ancestor's Chosen) and then gain lots of life to win with a [Test of Endurance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Test of Endurance). I had [Hanna, Ship's Navigator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hanna, Ship's Navigator) to return the Test of Endurance if I milled it, and a [Reya Dawnbringer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reya Dawnbringer) as a back-up plan...  
  
Never came close to working. On a good night I might be able to delay a Psychatog deck by 1 or 2 turns.
posts.html:
I tried this rogue blue/ white standard deck back in Odyssey block that would mill itself using stuff like Mental Note, Think Tank, Reviving Vapors or even Cephalid Vandal to get big stuff into the graveyard... Pedantic Learning would be a handy way to draw counters and bounce while I was doing that. The goal was to Breath of Life an Ancestor's Chosen and then gain lots of life to win with a Test of Endurance. I had Hanna, Ship's Navigator to return the Test of Endurance if I milled it, and a Reya Dawnbringer as a back-up plan...

Never came close to working. On a good night I might be able to delay a Psychatog deck by 1 or 2 turns.

This card deserves a much higher rating. Just because it can't fit into any old deck doesn't make it bad.  
  
Like aforementioned, run this with [Jace's Erasure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace's Erasure) and something that reveals the top card of your library, such as [Wizened Snitches](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wizened Snitches) or [Sphinx of Jwar Isle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sphinx of Jwar Isle). Whenever you draw a card, you get to take a look at the next card up; If it's a card you don't want you can mill it with the erasure, if you want the next card though you can keep it there and mill your opponent's top card instead (if it's good, that is). If your next card is a land and you don't need it, mill it then draw again. This card could be an especially efficient deck thinner if ran with Scry cards or cards with Scry-like functions such as [Sage Owl](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sage Owl). Need I not mention [Crucible of Worlds](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crucible of Worlds); ensure a land drop almost every turn and even more card acceleration.  
  
Now if you'll excuse me gentlemen, I'm off to build a deck.... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
